Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: Dimensions: Parallel Evolutionary Radiations in Protea and Pelargonium in the Greater Cape Floristic Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
Current approaches to predicting changes in community structure and function fail to consider relationships between species' attributes that affect their ecological function, genetic variation underlying those functional traits, and the dynamics of the communities of which they are part. This project will focus on Protea and Pelargonium, two South African plant genera that have undergone dramatic diversification and currently span two biodiversity hot spots, the fynbos and succulent karoo biomes in the Greater Cape Floristic Region (GFCR). This project will develop an understanding of functional trait variation in both genetic and evolutionary contexts, allowing predictions of the characteristics of communities in which they occur and the resilience of those communities to climate change. The project will examine detailed relationships between functional traits, photosynthesis, water use efficiency and leaf life span, including the genetic basis of trait variation and rates of trait diversification. This information will be used to examine effects of taxonomic and trait diversity on ecosystem resilience in response to fire cycle interval.

The project will expose postdoctoral scholars, graduate students, undergraduates and high school students to international research, including students actively recruited from underserved populations both in the US and South Africa. It will actively enhance conservation infrastructure by working closely in all aspects of the project with the South African National Biodiversity Institute (SANBI) to promote biodiversity science, policy and conservation action.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the evolution of two important plant groups in the Greater Cape Floristic Region of South Africa, an area with some of the highest plant species diversities on earth. Our goals were to reconstruct the evolutionary relationships and to understand how these two groups, Proteas and Pelargoniums, have evolved in response to past climate change in South Africa. We investigated how the characteristics of different species are related to variation in environment (e.g., precipitation and temperature gradients, fire regime), and how variation among species in these genera is related to the composition and trait values in the plant communities to which they belong. With this knowledge, we hope to provide insight into both the evolutionary history of the diversification of the Cape flora, as well as to how it may change in response to ongoing climate change.

 We conducted extensive field work to sample as many species of these two genera as possible. Field data on leaf and plant characteristics were collected to analyze relationships among traits, and between traits and environmental variables. Leaf samples of these species were collected to provide DNA for Next Generation sequencing. Sequence data allowed us to create a new phylogeny for each of these important plant groups, and these phylogenies form the basis for evaluating how ecologically relevant plant characteristics have changed over evolutionary time.

 We also conducted detailed analyses of genetic diversity on one species per genus - the widespread species Protea repens and Pelargonium scabrum. Analysis of multiple populations of each species indicates that there is widespread genetic variation in both, and that both neutral (isolation by distance) and non-neutral (natural selection) evolutionary processes have driven these genetic differences.

 For Pelargonium, we have documented extensive phenotypic variation among species for functional traits - i.e., those traits related to the plants' success in their local habitats. For example, we find that groups of species originating in regions with winter vs. summer rainfall have very divergent physiological responses to drought. We tested a widely-held hypothesis about the relationships among plant traits - the Leaf Economic Spectrum hypothesis, that proposes that relationships among some plant functional traits are driven by fundamental tradeoffs that are independent of phylogeny. Our results clearly demonstrate that this is not true - even closely related groups of species of Pelargonium differences differ in sign, i.e., positive vs. negative relationships for some trait-environment associations. Patterns of trait integration are also group-specific.

In analyses of extremely diverse communities in the Kouga-Baviaanskloof region, we found that functional trait values were weakly associated with most spatial environmental gradients and only showed trends with respect to vegetation class and time since fire. However, plots showed greater compositional and functional stability through time than expected based on null models. We found clear evidence for functional distinctions between vegetation classes, suggesting strong environmental filtering most likely driven by fire dynamics. However, there was little evidence of filtering effects along environmental gradients within vegetation classes, suggesting largely neutral assembly processes at this scale, likely the result of high functional redundancy among species in the regional pool.

We resurveyed plots in the longest running set of permanent vegetation plots in the Fynbos of South Africa (44 years). We found a significant decline in plot species diversity driven by increasingly severe post-fire summer weather events (affecting perennial herbs and graminoids) and alien plant invasion (affecting shrub species). The observed differences in the response of major growth forms and fire-response types could drive major shifts in ecosystem structure and function such as altered fire behavior, hydrology and carbon storage. This is the first example of climate change impacts on biodiversity in the hyperdiverse Cape Floristic Region and demonstrates an important interaction between extreme weather and disturbance by fire that may make flammable ecosystems particularly sensitive to climate change.

In addition to these research results, we are also developing important research resources. A reference transcriptome has been published for Protea repens and transcriptome data is being collected for Pelargonium. We also have done sequencing for one species in each genus, with the goal of assembling and annotating full genome sequences for each.

We trained 5 postdoctoral researchers and 6 graduate students during the course of the project. They participated in the field work in South Africa, and in the analysis and interpretation of the data we collected. They learned new skills in such areas as phylogenetics, population genomics, physiological ecology and data analysis. 

 Fifteen papers have been published to date, and papers on the evolution of trait-trait and trait-environment relationships for each genus, as well as on reconstruction of ancestral character states are forthcoming.
